Award.AwardTitle: A Scholarship Project to Increase the Recruitment and Retention of Students in the Sciences

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will award scholarships to 26 students, in three cohorts, in the following STEM disciplines: Biology, Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Chemistry, Computer Science, Mathematics, and Physics. In its selection, the college will take heightened interest in academically-promising underrepresented minority and first-generation students with financial need. By carefully targeting recruitment efforts and providing mentoring during the first two years at college, the project will create a constructive environment to nurture students in order to increase retention and persistence in their chosen STEM majors. The project will increase the number of talented STEM majors with the potential to contribute to the advancement of knowledge in a broad range of scientific endeavors, and will train a diverse group of students for eventual employment in STEM fields.

In order to successfully retain students, the project will include a recruitment plan that integrates individualized outreach to students identified in collaboration with Community Based Organizations, enrollment in an exclusive First-Year Seminar taught by STEM faculty, STEM Faculty Liaisons in each of the science departments serving as academic advisors, mentors, and facilitators, and a variety of on- and off-campus learning activities. The project's objectives during the Scholars' first year are: (1) to prepare and support the S-STEM Scholars for a successful undergraduate career, (2) to provide continuing practice for the skills necessary for STEM, and (3) to build and nurture a sense of community among the S-STEM Scholar cohorts. During their sophomore year, each S-STEM Scholar will continue to be closely mentored by their STEM Faculty Liaison advisor, who will support and encourage their participation in various STEM opportunities including faculty-student research, peer-mentoring, colloquia, preferential residence in Gettysburg College's Science House as well as work-related internship opportunities with institutional industry partners. Assessment of the efficacy of these different activities will help contribute to expanding the knowledge base regarding the circumstances under which scholarship projects of this type are successful.

POR.DRECONTENT:
They key outcome of Gettysburg College's NSF S-STEM Grant (1458644) is the development of our STEM Scholars Program to attract, retain, and support low-income academically talented students, with an emphasis on students from groups that are historically underrepresented in the sciences, to study STEM disciplines at a selective liberal arts college. Our student-centered and evidence-based approach included close partnerships with Community Based Organizations, a STEM-focused pre-orientation program, a First-Year Seminar course, and a supportive community of life-long learners via fellow STEM Scholars peers and STEM Faculty Liaison mentors. Our model could be implemented at other higher education institutions who wish to increase their ability to attract and retain a higher diversity of students in STEM. Importantly, this NSF S-STEM award has also supported an increased interaction between science faculty and admissions office staff to synergistically increase our ability to attract STEM prospective students. Both the pre-orientation program and First-Year Seminar have been successful in helping our STEM Scholars build self-confidence, a sense of belonging in STEM and hone important skills related to quantitative literacy and science communication, while also supporting them to adjust to the rigorous demands of a liberal arts educational experience. Paramount to all of this, Gettysburg College's STEM Scholars Program has been successful in retaining over 80% of recruited students in S-STEM supported STEM majors and in contributing to an increase in the total number of URMs students pursuing STEM majors at our institution.
